bestBHT.bht: In handling the abundance of contributions being ministered, Paul was cautious to prevent any blame. He associated trustworthy individuals with the task to avoid suspicions of embezzlement or personal gain. This display of circumspection and modesty protected the integrity of the ministry. Paul arranged for the abundance to be administered in a manner that would avert any accusations. His carefulness and solicitude ensured that no one could question the faithful stewardship of the resources entrusted to him.

Henry Alford: taking heed of this, that no one blame us.
in the matter of this abundance (of contributions) which is being ministered by us.
which is being ministered by us.
Albert Barnes: Paul felt how dangerous it was for ministers to have much to do with money matters.
He knew how easy it might be for his enemies to raise the charge that he had embezzled the funds and appropriated them to his own use.
Nothing can be more wise than the example of Paul here, that they should have associated with them others who have the entire confidence of the churches.
Marvin Vincent: Avoiding this [στελλομενοι τουτο] . The verb, which occurs only here and 2 Thessalonians 3:6, means to arrange or provide for... Connect with we have sent, ver. 18.

Abundance [αδροτητι] . Only here in the New Testament. Lit., thickness, and so, of the vigor or strength of the human body or of plants... The A. V. abundance is better than Rev. bounty, which, though properly implying abundance, is currently taken as synonymous with gift.
The reference is to the large contribution.
John Calvin: The more upright a person is, in that proportion does Satan assail him by every kind of contrivance, if he can by any means shake his credit.
Hence the higher the station in which we are placed, we must so much the more carefully imitate Paul’s circumspection and modesty.
He was not so lifted up, as not to be under control equally with any individual of the flock.
Philip Schaff: The word 'readiness' means 'thickness,' 'fulness,' 'exuberance;' and refers probably to the largeness of their contribution...
...possible surmises as to his strict fidelity, which he would take means to ward off...
Archibald T. Robertson: Avoiding this (στελλομενο τουτο). Present middle participle of στελλω, old verb, to set, to arrange. So 'arranging for ourselves this.'

That any man should blame us (μη τις ημας μωμησητα). Literally, 'lest any one blame us' (negative purpose with μη and first aorist middle subjunctive of μωμεομα. See on 2 Corinthians 6:3, only other N.T. example).
Bounty (αδροτητ). Old word from αδρος, thick, stout, ripe, rich, great as in 1 Kings 1:9; 2 Kings 10:6. Only here in N.T.
John Gill: There is an allusion in these words to mariners, who, when sensible of danger, steer their course another way, in order to shun a rock and secure themselves.
This shows the good conduct, and great prudence of the apostle, and his care and solicitude that the ministry be not blamed.
...for it is added, in this abundance which is administered by us: which designs the very large contributions which were made by the churches...

bhtAttempts.bht: In 2 Corinthians 8:20, the apostle Paul urges the recipients of the abundance of contributions being ministered by him to take heed, ensuring that no one blames them. Paul was aware of the dangers and possible surmises that could arise if ministers closely handled money matters, so he took precautions to associate others who had the complete trust of the churches. This not only demonstrated his circumspection and modesty but also guarded against any accusations of embezzlement or personal appropriation. Paul's carefulness and solicitude for the integrity of the ministry is evident as he arranges for the abundance to be administered in a manner that avoids any blame or controversy.

In handling the abundance of contributions being ministered, Paul was cautious to prevent any blame. He associated trustworthy individuals with the task to avoid suspicions of embezzlement or personal gain. This display of circumspection and modesty protected the integrity of the ministry. Paul arranged for the abundance to be administered in a manner that would avert any accusations. His carefulness and solicitude ensured that no one could question the faithful stewardship of the resources entrusted to him.

Paul, in 2 Corinthians 8:20, emphasizes the importance of avoiding blame in the handling of the abundance of contributions being ministered. He takes precautions and associates trustworthy individuals to counter any suspicions of misappropriation or personal gain. This not only safeguards the integrity of the ministry but also demonstrates Paul's circumspection and modesty. His careful arrangement and administration of the abundance serves to protect against any accusations and ensure that the stewardship of resources is beyond reproach.

Paul, in his letter to the Corinthians, urges caution and vigilance in handling the abundance of contributions being ministered. He arranges for trustworthy individuals to be involved, avoiding any blame or suspicions of misappropriation. This demonstrates his circumspection and modesty, ensuring the integrity of the ministry. By administering the abundance carefully, Paul safeguards against accusations and upholds the faithful stewardship of the resources entrusted to him.

Paul's concern in 2 Corinthians 8:20 is to prevent any blame from being cast upon him for the handling of the abundant contributions being ministered. He takes precautions against this, arranging for trustworthy individuals to assist in the administration. By doing so, he safeguards against suspicions of embezzlement or personal gain. This wise example demonstrates Paul's circumspection and modesty, while also ensuring the integrity of the ministry. His careful arrangement and administration of these contributions serve to protect against any accusations and maintain the faithful stewardship of the resources entrusted to him.
